The chairman of the Senate Judiciary and Rules Committee is denying the opportunity for mandatory minimum reforms to be heard.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

We are one more step towards victory! Just this Monday, the Idaho House of Representatives passed HB 99 – Mandatory Minimums with a majority floor vote. It is now headed to the Senate Judiciary and Rules Committee. Most representatives shared their support for this bill as it was debated on the House floor and we thank all of you that were able to reach out to your elected officials to ask for their “yes” vote on this bill.

Nevertheless, our fight is far from over. We need to focus our attention and collective power towards the Senate Judiciary and Rules Committee. The chairman of that committee, Senator Todd Lakey (R - District 12), is denying the opportunity for HB 99 to have a hearing despite the overwhelming public support the bill has received.

The time for action has come again.

Now more than ever we need your support. We urge you to contact Senator Lakey and tell him to schedule HB 99 for a hearing in the Senate Judiciary and Rules Committee. Idahoans deserve the opportunity to elevate their stories and experiences, especially in emphasizing why this bill is necessary for our Idaho communities.

HB 99 will restore judicial discretion and reduce the power that prosecutors hold over sentencing. With only a few weeks left in the 2019 Legislative Session, there’s no time to waste. Idaho is in desperate need of sentencing reform and we can’t wait another year to bring meaningful change to our criminal justice system.

Contact Senator Lakey today and ask that he promptly schedule HB 99 for a public hearing.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Kathy Griesmyer
Policy Director, ACLU of Idaho
